newsitem.title: MOLDOVA: Moldova deputies back gas debt deal with Russia. [CORRECTED 12:46 GMT 26/12]
newsitem.headline: Moldova deputies back gas debt deal with Russia. [CORRECTED 12:46 GMT 26/12]

text.p: Moldova's parliament on Tuesday gave its backing to a government's plan to pay a large part of the country's debt to Russia's gas monopoly Gazprom by issuing state bonds worth a total of $140 million.
In line with the government's agreement with Gazprom ratified by 56 votes to 14 against, the Finance Ministry will issue 2,000 bonds, worth $70,000 each, and hand them over to Gazprom.
Russia is the only natural gas supplier to the energy-starved and cash-short Moldova which is to get three billion (corrects from million) cubic metres of gas this year, same as in 1995.
By December 1, Moldova's total gas debt soared to $401 million from $281.7 million on January 1, Mihai Cebotari, head of the Energy Resources Department, told deputies.

He said that in line with an earlier accord with Gazprom Chisinau's officially recorded gas debt is $183.4 million. The remaining part is the debt to be paid by the country's eastern Dnepr rebel region which broke away in 1990.
Cebotari said the government had assumed $140 million of Chisinau's debt to Gazprom and the rest is to be paid by consumer companies.

"Moldova is now able to pay with its goods or dollars only for some 50 percent of Russian gas imports...Gazprom has put up condition -- either we pay our debts or are disconnected from gas deliveries," he said urging the law-makers to vote.
Cebotari said that Moldova would get a grace period of two years during which it would only have to pay to Gazprom an annual intesrest of 7.5 percent on the $140 million bond issue.

But an explanatory note saying that "the Moldovan side can make payments on these securities also with deliveries of material resources, stakes in its privatised companies and other means", angered some nationalist legislators.
"This means...our children and even grandchildren will owe to, and depend on, Gazprom," said one of them, Lidia Istrati.
"We have to ratify this agreement not to remain without gas this winter," said deputy parliament chairman Dumitru Motpan.
Cebotari said Moldova buys Russian gas much below its world price of $80 per 1,000 cubic metres because it transports large amounts to the Balkans across its territory.

In line with the ratified document, the bonds will be freely traded on Russian and Moldovan exchanges and over-the-counter markets, as well as in third countries. The Finance Ministry has to work out the mechanism.
"This agreement is very advantageous for Moldova...It allows us to catch up with the necessary rate of payments for gas within the next two years," Cebotari said.
A delegation of Moldova's government is expected to present the ratified agreement to Gazprom officials in Moscow on Wednesday.
